speaker: Frasier
text: So I decided it was time I got to know some of my colleagues in the media.

speaker: Niles
text: But a convention?  You've never shown any interest before.

speaker: Frasier
text: They've never held one in Aspen before!

speaker: Niles
text: Just think: hundreds of radio psychiatrists all in the same location.  One well-timed avalanche and the dignity of the entire psychiatric profession would be restored.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_laughing_] Oh, good one.  I can always count on you for some witty retort.

speaker: Niles
text: Mmm... I insult you and you compliment me.  Could the request for a favour be far behind?

speaker: Frasier
text: Damn, you are perceptive.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, stop it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, all right.  Listen, Niles -- I'd like you to do my show for me for the week I'm gone.

speaker: Niles
text: Me standing in for you?  I'm sorry, Frasier.  I couldn't presume to fill those big floppy red shoes of yours.

speaker: Frasier
text: Please.  Please, Niles.  Look, I'm begging you.  The station wants to replace me with Helen Grogan, better known as Ma' Nature.  She does a gardening show and I'm just a little worried that a week of discussing well-rotted manure will weaken my listener base.

speaker: Niles
text: It hasn't yet!

speaker: Frasier
text: Very well.  You leave me no alternative but to call in my marker.

speaker: Niles
text: [_worriedly_] What marker?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I think you know.

speaker: Niles
text: You wouldn't.

speaker: Frasier
text: I would.

speaker: Niles
text: You can't!

speaker: Frasier
text: I will.

speaker: Niles
text: That was three years ago.

speaker: Frasier
text: I don't recall there being any statute of limitations. I distinctly recall that when you asked me to go out with Maris's sister, you said that you would owe me one forever.

speaker: Niles
text: But you only spent one evening with Brie.  That hardly compares with what you're asking me to endure.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh?  Shall I refresh your memory?  Midway through the opera her ermine muff began to tremble.  As it turned out she had used it to smuggle in her adorably incontinent Chihuahua. Just as I thought we'd reached the low point of the evening I suddenly felt a sandpaper tongue licking my earlobe.  Alas it did not belong to little Herve!  Fortunately my shriek coincided with the on-stage murder of Gondolfo!  Roz will expect you on Monday at two.

speaker: Niles
text: For your information Brie had a very tough road-a-ho growing up.  It's not easy going through life with one nostril.

speaker: Frasier
text: Did I mention she had a cold that night?

speaker: Niles
text: Monday at two it is.  [_N.B. This episode was originally written with Frasier as the center of the action, but Kelsey Grammer had a medical emergency, and they re-wrote Niles into the part._] **STRANGER IN A STRANGE LAND** _Scene 2 -- KACL. Niles is sitting in the booth listening to a caller drone on with an extremely bored look on his face.  Roz is just sitting back smiling. _

speaker: Linda
text: [_v.o._] And now we're at the point where all communication has broken down.  He won't even listen to me.

speaker: Niles
text: [_bored_] Linda-

speaker: Linda
text: Do you know how annoying that is -- not to be listened to?

speaker: Niles
text: [_bored_] Linda-

speaker: Linda
text: It's driving me crazy.  I was hoping maybe you would speak to him directly.

speaker: Niles
text: Excuse me one moment. [_presses the cough button_] Thank you for the brilliant job of call screening, Roz.  How do I get out of this?

speaker: Roz
text: Did you ever think of saying you've other callers on the line?

speaker: Niles
text: [_back on air_] Linda, I'd love to go into this in more depth but unfortunately we're nearly out of time and Roz has lots of other callers waiting anxiously on the line.

speaker: Roz
text: Actually, Dr. Crane, all lines are open!

speaker: Linda
text: So you can talk to him?  Good.  I'm putting him on the line right now.  Go ahead!

speaker: Niles
text: All right.  Murray -- you're dealing with your problem in a very self-destructive manner.  It won't be solved by refusing to eat.  Do you hear me? _There is a moment's silence on the other end then a cat meows. Niles rolls his eyes at the stupidity of it all._

speaker: Linda
text: Oh my God, it's working.  He's eating!  Dr. Crane, what did you say to him?

speaker: Niles
text: Well I'd like to tell you but that would violate Doctor-Cat confidentiality! [_Roz signals that the show is about to finish_] Oh, well Seattle, I'm afraid we're out of time.  This is Dr. Niles Crane.  One down, four to go.  See you tomorrow! [_talking through the intercom to Roz_] That little bit of sabotage was not amusing.

speaker: Roz
text: Then why did coffee come out my nose? _Bulldog comes into the booth with his usual trolley of tricks and sound effects._

speaker: Bulldog
text: Hey, Dr. Doolittle.  I heard your show.  It didn't suck!

speaker: Niles
text: Ah.  "Dear diary..."

speaker: Bulldog
text: So how's it feel?

speaker: Niles
text: Like I'm walking away from my lamppost and counting the bills in my garter belt!

speaker: Bulldog
text: OK. [_blows his whistle_] Both of you get out of here.  I gotta set up for my show.  I got Reggie McLemore on my show today. Don't ask me why.

speaker: Niles
text: I wasn't even going to ask who.

speaker: Roz
text: He's a guard for the Sonics.

speaker: Bulldog
text: He used to be unstoppable - 20 points a game easy.  Now he's in the "tank."  Just what I need on my show -- a loser.

speaker: Bulldog
text: Oh look -- there he is now.  What an overpaid, worthless piece of... [_Reggie comes through the door_] HEY, REGGIE MY MAN!

speaker: Reggie
text: You never call me unless you need tickets, man.  What's up with that? _Bulldog and Reggie go through some sort of ritual, grabbing each other's heads and knocking them against each other's whilst shouting. Needless to say, Niles looks on bemused._

speaker: Bulldog
text: I love this guy. [_introducing Reggie to Roz_] Reggie McLemore, Roz Doyle.

speaker: Roz
text: Hi, I'm a big fan of yours.

speaker: Reggie
text: Thanks.

speaker: Bulldog
text: [_noticing Niles_] I'd introduce you to this guy but he doesn't know squat about sports.

speaker: Niles
text: On the contrary -- in prep school I was an ardent sportsman. Until an inflamed instep forced me to resign from the croquet club.

speaker: Niles
text: I'll see myself out.

speaker: Reggie
text: Wait a minute.  You're the shrink.  I heard you in my car on the way over.

speaker: Niles
text: Dr. Niles Crane.  It's a pleasure.

speaker: Reggie
text: Hey Doc, wait.  You sounded like you really knew what you were talking about. There's this little problem I've been having and I was wondering if maybe you could help me out?

speaker: Niles
text: What is it?

speaker: Reggie
text: See, for the last two weeks, every time I get my hands on the pill I choke.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, have you tried mashing it with a spoon?

speaker: Reggie
text: [_deadpan stare_] You don't watch much basketball, do you? It's my game, man.  Because of me we've lost six in a row.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh.  Well, I'm not very well-versed in sports psychology, but I could certainly schedule a session.

speaker: Reggie
text: No, no.  I need something fast.  We got Phoenix tonight.

speaker: Niles
text: This is highly irregular, but since you're pressed there are some exercises I can suggest.

speaker: Reggie
text: Oh, great.  Thanks, man.  Just name it -- tickets to any game you want.

speaker: Niles
text: There's nothing wrong with your sense of humour.  Have a seat.

speaker: Niles
text: We'll start with a positive visualisation.  I want you to close your eyes.  Take a deep breath. [_Reggie does this_] Good. I want you to imagine yourself on the playing surface doing whatever it is you actually do.  Tell me what you see.

speaker: Reggie
text: OK.  Kemp's passing me the ball.  I'm bringing it up court. I'm dribbling.

speaker: Niles
text: [_patting him supportively_] Don't worry about your appearance. [_Reggie looks strangely at him_] Start again.  I'll just be quiet. _Back in the booth Roz is observing the goings-on.  Bulldog is busy setting up for his show_

speaker: Roz
text: Can I ask you a favour?

speaker: Bulldog
text: Yeah, forget it.  He's married!

speaker: Roz
text: Hey!  That's pretty offensive.  Why did you assume that's what I wanted?

speaker: Bulldog
text: OK, then.  What did you want?

speaker: Roz
text: Well, I don't know.  I just wondered if...

speaker: Bulldog
text: [_blowing a horn in her face_] Time's up.  Oh, by the way, if you're so hungry for some good-looking athletic guy, why won't you go out with me?

speaker: Roz
text: [_holding her hand up above Bulldog's head_] If you're not at least this tall you can't go on this ride.

speaker: Niles
text: This next exercise is designed to block negative feelings. I've tried it myself.  Simply take a moment.  Think of something comforting from childhood: a stuffed animal, a dog- eared copy of Middlemarch. [_again Reggie looks baffled at Niles_] You may have other memories!

speaker: Bulldog
text: Come on, Reggie.  Ticket!

speaker: Reggie
text: I gotta run.  Thanks a lot, Doc -- I'll give it a try. _Reggie holds out his hand to slap Niles.  Niles fumbles about trying to do some form of high-five._

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, wait.  I saw this.  It has steps!

speaker: Reggie
text: [_simply going for the option of ruffling Niles's hair_] Later, man. _FADE TO:  Scene 3 -- Frasier's Apartment Daphne and Martin are sitting in the living room.  Martin is watching the basketball game on the television. _

speaker: Daphne
text: You know, according to this article...

speaker: Martin
text: No, quiet! [_Daphne looks angry while Martin remonstrates with the television_] That's 3 seconds.  Come on.  He's camping out in the middle.  No, don't double the ball -- they'll just sling it around for a three.  There it is -- just like I said! [_despairingly_] Ohhhh!  Oh, time out -- sure, now you listen to me. [_to Daphne_] Can you believe this?  Two minutes ago we were up six points, now...

speaker: Daphne
text: Quiet -- this is my favourite commercial!  No, don't pick that floor cleaner.  It'll give your floors waxy build-up!  No, don't do it.  DON'T DO IT!  D'ohhh!!

speaker: Martin
text: It's completely different.

speaker: Daphne
text: That'll be Dr. Crane.  It'll be a pleasure to be around one man who's not obsessed with sports.

speaker: Niles
text: Hello, Daphne. [_notices the television on_] Ooh, the Sonics are on!  Excuse me.

speaker: Niles
text: So, Dad...

speaker: Martin
text: Hold it, Niles -- there's only nine seconds to go.

speaker: Niles
text: What's the score?

speaker: Martin
text: What do you care? [_goes back to shouting at the television_] Get it to McLemore.  To McLemore -- he's got the hot hand. Yes.  Come on, Reggie... UNBELIEVABLE!  SONICS WIN! [_claps his hands in delight_]

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, this is fantastic, Dad.  Do you know...?

speaker: Martin
text: Shush, Niles.  I want to see the replay.  Get it to McLemore. UNBELIEVABLE! [_claps his hands in delight_]

speaker: Niles
text: You know, Dad, you might be interested to know...

speaker: Martin
text: Quiet, Niles -- I want to see the interview.

speaker: Sportscaster
text: Reggie -- got a minute?  Great game tonight.  Seems like your slump is over.

speaker: Reggie
text: Yeah, I was really feeling it out there tonight.

speaker: Sportscaster
text: What turned it around for you?

speaker: Reggie
text: Well, I was having a little problem getting my head together, but this radio shrink really helped me out. Dr. Niles Crane... [_gestures thumbs-up to the camera._]

speaker: Sportscaster
text: Well, good luck against Utah.

speaker: Reggie
text: Thanks a lot.

speaker: Sportscaster
text: Let's head it back upstairs. _By this point Martin is looking incredulously at Niles who just sits there smug with himself._

speaker: Martin
text: You?

speaker: Niles
text: [_laughing_] Is that so hard to believe?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah!

speaker: Daphne
text: When did you talk to him?

speaker: Niles
text: He was on Bulldog's show today.  We had a brief session in the hallway -- not more than two minutes.

speaker: Martin
text: You turned Reggie's game around in only two minutes?

speaker: Niles
text: You could be a little less surprised.  I am a skilled psychiatrist.  During sixteen years in the field I have developed certain instincts.

speaker: Martin
text: I gotta say -- I'm impressed.

speaker: Daphne
text: Yes.  I'm starting to think I should spend an hour or two on the couch with you.

speaker: Martin
text: Are you kidding?  With Niles, it'd only take two minutes! _Daphne smiles and goes through to the kitchen.  Niles drinks his sherry looking at Martin who is grinning._

speaker: Niles
text: Thanks, Dad! **HOOPLA**  _Scene 4 - KACL. Niles is walking through the corridor to the booth._  Worker 1: Hey Doc -- great job!  Go Sonics! Worker 2: You the man!

speaker: Niles
text: Thank you.  Er... same to you. _From inside another booth someone gives Niles a thumbs up.  Niles returns the compliment before noticing his thumb._

speaker: Niles
text: Heavens.  I need a clip and a buff. _Niles goes into the studio to find Roz in the booth with the day's newspaper._

speaker: Roz
text: There he is -- the toast of Seattle.  I suppose you knew you'd made the sports section of the paper this morning?

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, I'd heard.  I must admit I find this all a bit mystifying.  Do people really care this much about a basketball game?

speaker: Roz
text: Are you kidding?  This is Seattle.  It rains nine months out of the year.  We take our indoor sports very seriously.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, I know you always have!

speaker: Roz
text: [_forcing a smile_] You're a hero today so I'm going to let that one go.

speaker: Bulldog
text: Pucker up, baby -- I'm planting a big wet one on ya! [_grabs Niles' head and kisses him on the forehead._]

speaker: Niles
text: [_shocked_] Well, there's a layer of skin I'll be exfoliating this evening.

speaker: Bulldog
text: [_overjoyed_] I had 200 bucks on the Sonics!

speaker: Niles
text: Isn't gambling illegal?

speaker: Bulldog
text: [_to Roz_] Isn't he the cutest?

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, yeah.

speaker: Bulldog
text: OK.  I hope you don't feel this way about chicks 'cause I got one of the Sonics' cheerleaders coming on my show today and she really wants to see you.

speaker: Roz
text: Believe it or not, Bulldog, not every man's dream woman is a pom-pom-shaking half-time half-wit.

speaker: Niles
text: Is she the head cheerleader?

speaker: Bulldog
text: Yeah.  And she's coming in costume.

speaker: Roz
text: Of course she is -- it's radio! [_pushes Bulldog out the booth before turning to Niles with a stack of papers_] Look at these faxes that came for you.

speaker: Niles
text: Faxes? [_reads them_] "Seattle thanks you."  "You're the Sonics MVP." [_turns to Roz inquisitively_]

speaker: Roz
text: Most Valuable Player.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh!  "You're a genius."  With the less common J spelling but still, his point is well taken.

speaker: Roz
text: I bet you're feeling pretty good about yourself?

speaker: Niles
text: Suddenly I'm being revered as a god by the same troglodytes who, in junior high school, tried to pack me into my own briefcase.  It's glorious.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, I almost forgot the best part. [_goes into her pocket_] Reggie sent these tickets for tonight's game over.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh.  Well, I suppose I can't disappoint my new fans.  Tell me, does one still wear a white sweater jauntily tied around the neck to these things?

speaker: Roz
text: If one wants to get the crap beaten out of one! _Roz goes into her booth. Meanwhile Martin comes through the studio door._

speaker: Martin
text: Hey.

speaker: Niles
text: Dad.  What a surprise.

speaker: Martin
text: I'm not interrupting you or anything, am I?

speaker: Niles
text: No, no.  Come on in.  Is everything alright?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh sure, sure.  I was just having lunch at McGinty's and some of the guys would really like to meet you and I was hoping that maybe after your show you'd stop in there for a drink. I mean, I wouldn't ask you but some of these guys are my best buddies.

speaker: Niles
text: Well actually Dad, Reggie just sent over these tickets to tonight's game.  I was going to ask you to go, but since...

speaker: Martin
text: [_grabbing the tickets out Niles's hands_] To hell with those guys, I'm there!

speaker: Niles
text: I have to tell you I'm finding all this attention a bit overwhelming.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh come on -- you deserve it.  You're a hero.

speaker: Niles
text: Perhaps it's time we put all this in perspective.  The only real heroes are the fine athletes who worked so hard for two hours to win that game.  My contribution was minimal at best. _Bulldog opens the door to reveal the head cheerleader -- blonde, buxom and wearing very tight clothing. _

speaker: Bulldog
text: What did I tell ya, Doc?

speaker: Cheerleader
text: Which one of you won the game for us last night?

speaker: Niles
text: [_pushing Martin out of the way_] That would be me! _The cheerleader goes over to "congratulate" Niles who looks happily shocked.  End of Act 1  Act 2_ **AY, THERE'S THE RUB** _Scene 1 -- The Sonics game that night. Martin, Niles and Daphne are walking along the baseline to their front row seats. Martin is just saying goodbye to a fellow spectator. _

speaker: Martin
text: Nice seeing you too.

speaker: Niles
text: Dad, it really isn't necessary to tell everyone we bump into that [_loudly_] I'm the one Reggie credited with last night's victory!

speaker: Spectator
text: That was you?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, yeah.  That's my son Niles Crane.

speaker: Niles
text: [_sitting down on the baseline seats, unaware of their importance_] They must have sold too many tickets.  They've stuck us in these folding chairs.

speaker: Martin
text: Wow.  Right on the hardwood, five feet from the baseline. _Niles chuckles along with Martin before turning to Daphne with a baffled look._

speaker: Daphne
text: It's like front row orchestra, stage right.

speaker: Niles
text: Ooh.

speaker: Martin
text: Man, we're so close we're gonna get our teeth rattled when they center-pick.

speaker: Daphne
text: It's like sitting close enough to get hit by Placido Domingo's spit.

speaker: Reggie
text: Hey, N.C. -- you made it.

speaker: Niles
text: I beg your pardon?  Oh, "N.C."  I thought you said Nancy. For a second it was prep school all over again. [_introducing_] Let me introduce - Reggie McLemore, Daphne Moon, and this...

speaker: Martin
text: Marty Crane, Niles's Dad.  I'm a big fan.  I want you to know I never lost faith in you.  Not when you were in your slump. Not when you tanked it in the playoffs.  Not even when all my friends were calling you "Reggie HacLemore" [_laughs_]

speaker: Reggie
text: What?

speaker: Niles
text: This might be a good time to try that negative thought- blocking exercise.

speaker: Reggie
text: Yeah, OK.  You guys enjoy the game.  I'll see you afterwards. _Niles puts out his hand to "slap some skin" with Reggie but he just walks off.  The buzzer goes and Niles just about has a coronary._

speaker: Niles
text: What the hell was that?!

speaker: Martin
text: That's the end of the shooter round.  The coach is about to send the starting five in for the tip-off.

speaker: Daphne
text: The stage manager just called places.

speaker: Niles
text: Ooh. _The scene SWITCHES to later on in the game.  Daphne and Martin are nowhere to be seen so Niles is sitting by himself.  He is surrounded by spectators out of their chairs booing and shouting at the court._

speaker: Niles
text: I gather Reggie's not performing up to par this evening?

speaker: Spectator
text: You got that from all the booing, huh?  Nice counselling, Doc -- he's been throwing up bricks all night!

speaker: Niles
text: Judging from that empty tureen of nachos and cheese you may be joining him. _The spectator has had enough and leaves. Reggie runs off the court to speak to Niles._

speaker: Reggie
text: Doc, Doc, you gotta help me out here.  I don't know what's wrong.

speaker: Niles
text: Perhaps you've forgotten some of my advice.  Let's review quickly.  Did you empty your mind of negative thoughts?

speaker: Reggie
text: Yeah.

speaker: Niles
text: What about the imaging exercises?

speaker: Reggie
text: Yeah, yeah, I did all that.  What else did you tell me to do?

speaker: Niles
text: Nothing.  Bulldog called you, you ran back in.

speaker: Reggie
text: No, no, wait.  Right before that I rubbed your head.  I remember 'cause my hand smelled like peach and I thought, "What the hell does this guy wash his hair with?"

speaker: Niles
text: Well, you can't possibly think that my head is some sort of lucky charm?

speaker: Reggie
text: [_ruffling Niles's hair_] We'll know in a minute. _Reggie runs back on court smelling his hand.  Daphne and Martin return and sit down next to Niles._

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, I saw you talking to Reggie again.  I hope you gave him some more advice.

speaker: Niles
text: I tried to but he has this absurd idea that...

speaker: Martin
text: No, no, wait.

speaker: Announcer
text: McLemore shoots three.

speaker: Martin
text: Unbelievable.  What did you say to him?

speaker: Niles
text: I didn't say anything that he could possibly...

speaker: Daphne
text: Look, look.  He's stolen the ball.

speaker: Announcer
text: McLemore.  Three more.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_patting Niles on the knee_] Oh, Dr. Crane, you're a miracle worker.  What did you say to him?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, just something off the top of my head! _The scene FADES OUT with the crowd applauding again as Reggie obviously scores another.  Scene 2 -- Frasier's apartment. Martin is sitting in his chair.  Daphne is walking back from the front door having collected the post. _

speaker: Daphne
text: Ooh, isn't this nice?  Dr. Crane sent us a postcard from Aspen.

speaker: Martin
text: [_uninterested_] Great.  How's he doing?

speaker: Daphne
text: Let's see. [_reading the postcard_] "I delivered a speech at the conference last night.  I was especially pleased with my opening line: 'My fellow psychiatrists, as I watched you on the slopes today I realised I had never seen so many Freudians slip!'" _Daphne looks up in disgust at the pun.  Martin just simply stares deadpan straight ahead._

speaker: Daphne
text: [_still reading_] "As hard as you're laughing now, imagine the thunder of an auditorium of colleagues.  Well, see you Saturday, Frasier."  Well, I'd better get going.  I'm meeting Joe at the movies. [_checks her watch_] Oh, bloody hell -- it's later than I thought.

speaker: Martin
text: Enjoy.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_rushing out_] Yeah.  Enjoy your game.

speaker: Daphne
text: Dr. Crane.  Have fun at the game.

speaker: Niles
text: I'm afraid we won't be going.

speaker: Daphne
text: Ah.  That's too bad.

speaker: Niles
text: Want to know why?

speaker: Daphne
text: Not really. _The elevator door closes on Daphne.  Niles pokes his head round the door of Frasier's apartment and finds Martin on the phone to Duke._

speaker: Martin
text: [_into phone_] VIP parking.  Uh-huh.  That's courtside, pal. Right on the hardwood, I swear to God.  And Reggie said the seats are ours for the rest of the season.  I believe it's what they call "living large"... I don't know, somewhere on TV.  Yeah, OK.  I gotta go.  Bye! [_to Niles_] Let's go, Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: [_uneasily_] You know, Dad, I was thinking.  Maybe we shouldn't go to the game today.

speaker: Martin
text: [_laughing_] You know what I was thinking?  Maybe we shouldn't go to any of them. [_laughs again_] You know, that's one of the best things about this whole thing.  When was the last time you and I joked like this?  Well, we'd better get going, 'cause it's late.

speaker: Niles
text: Last night at the game, did you happen to notice when Reggie tousled my hair?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, yeah.  Let's go.

speaker: Niles
text: Somehow, someway, he's convinced himself that that's what he needs to do in order to play well.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh.  Well, can we talk about it in the car?

speaker: Niles
text: It has nothing to do with any advice I've given.  It's all some sort of bizarre superstition and Reggie wants to rub my head again before today's game.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, you know, a lot of athletes have weird superstitions.

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, but I'm a psychiatrist.  I can't let people think I'm treating the man when all I am is a rabbit's foot!  I'd be taking credit for something I don't deserve.

speaker: Martin
text: OK.  What would you be taking credit for?  Helping him.  What are you doing?  Helping him.  I'm getting my coat.

speaker: Niles
text: But I wouldn't be helping him as a psychiatrist.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, that's what's bugging you?  People thinking you're a good psychiatrist?

speaker: Niles
text: Exactly!

speaker: Martin
text: Are you a good psychiatrist?

speaker: Niles
text: Yes!

speaker: Martin
text: I'm getting my coat.

speaker: Niles
text: Dad, Dad, I'm sorry.  We're not going.

speaker: Martin
text: Aw, man, I knew you'd find some way to ruin this! [_throws his jacket to the floor_]

speaker: Niles
text: Dad-

speaker: Martin
text: Courtside season tickets; VIP parking.

speaker: Niles
text: Dad-

speaker: Martin
text: No.  Hell, you've got to have your reasons. [_mocking Niles_] "It's my ethics.  It's my integrity.  It's my allergies." Well, that's it. [_grabs his newspaper_] I'm never getting my hopes up again.

speaker: Niles
text: Dad, you can still watch the game on TV.

speaker: Martin
text: [_looking away from Niles_] I don't want to watch it on TV!

speaker: Niles
text: I'll get you a beer.

speaker: Martin
text: [_looking away from Niles_] I don't like beer!

speaker: Niles
text: Dad, you know I'm right.

speaker: Martin
text: Will you look me in the eye and answer me one question: would you still be doing this if these were courtside seats at the opera?

speaker: Niles
text: Yes.  My ethics are ethics.  And by the way -- where do you think I got those ethics?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, yeah.  Throw it back at me.  That's real mature! _Scene 3 -- The game. A security guard is standing outside the locker room.  Niles walks up to him. _

speaker: Niles
text: I'd like to talk to Mr. McLemore.

speaker: Guard
text: Who wants to see him?

speaker: Niles
text: Tell him N.C. is here.

speaker: Guard
text: Nancy?

speaker: Niles
text: No. [_spelling it out_] N-C. [_the guard disappears into the locker room_] What is so hard about that? _Reggie comes out looking worried.  The security guard is behind him and stands on the other side of the room._

speaker: Reggie
text: Damn man, where have you been?  I've got to be on court in five minutes. [_goes to rub Niles' head_]

speaker: Niles
text: [_putting his hand up_] Stop!  Before you rub your hands all over me, we need to talk. [_guard glances over worryingly_]

speaker: Reggie
text: What's up?

speaker: Niles
text: I'll come right to the point.  This entire affair has grown out of control.  I need to end it.

speaker: Reggie
text: What are you saying?  You're not coming down here any more?

speaker: Niles
text: Well, no.  We can still see each other to talk, but no touching. [_Again the guard looks over_] That part of our relationship is over. [_notices the guard staring_] Does this concern you?

speaker: Guard
text: It's starting to! [_he heads through to the locker room_]

speaker: Reggie
text: Come on, dude. [_reaches his hand out_]

speaker: Niles
text: No.  Now listen.  Do you really expect me to drop what I'm doing and race down here every day just so you can run your fingers over my head?

speaker: Reggie
text: Yeah.

speaker: Niles
text: Listen to me closely.  You are a gifted athlete with tremendous skill.  Marshal your talents.  Concentrate.  Focus. The key to your success is to trust your own God-given abilities.  It has nothing to do with my head!

speaker: Reggie
text: [_thinking_] It must be your hair.

speaker: Niles
text: [_losing his patience_] Will you stop it?  You're obsessing!

speaker: Reggie
text: Come on, man -- just let me touch it? _At this point the guard comes out the locker room, hears that last line and immediately turns round and walks away.  Niles looks exasperated._

speaker: Niles
text: No!  You have to look at this logically.  I can't come down here for every game and I certainly can't go with you when the team is on tour.  This is not a long-term solution.  What you need is legitimate therapy.  You want to start?  Come inside -- I'll give you a quick session.  We can proceed from there.

speaker: Reggie
text: Yeah, you're right, Doc.  What I need is a long-term solution.

speaker: Niles
text: Good. _Niles heads off into the locker room.  Reggie turns to one of his team-mates who has just came outside._

speaker: Reggie
text: Yo Frank, let me see those scissors. [_takes scissors out of his bag_] Coming, Doc. [_follows Niles into the locker room_]
